The eagle picks my eye
 The worm he licks my bones
Girl, you know the reason why

The girl he’s referring to is most likely Yoko Ono … the only reason why he isn’t already dead is the hope to see her again soon … But, at the same time, the reason for his depression and for his suicidal tendencies might at the same time be their temporary separation.
Even hate my rock and roll

In his life, there had been numerous occasions of John being self-conscious about his work. After the Beatles broke up, he  looked back at many of his past songs and discredited them as “throwaway garbage”.
Citation needed

Yes, I’m lonely
 Want to die
 Yes, I’m lonely
 Want to die

“Yer Blues”, conceptualised by John Lennon and eventually written by the Lennon-Paul McCartney pseudonym Lennon-McCartney, began its development in India.

These lines are not dramatised in an attempt to yank on listener’s heart strings. Rather, they are an accurate representation of Lennon’s thoughts at the time:

[…] when I wrote “I’m so lonely I want to die.” I wasn’t kidding. That’s how I felt…up there, trying to reach God and feeling suicidal.
And you know what it’s worth

“For what it’s worth” is a prefacing phrase used to indicate the speaker’s value of a sentence even if it’s expected to not give much consolation to the listener. Lennon here may be acknowledging an existing mutual understanding with the listener, “I know you know what I mean”; or despondently admitting that what he has to say isn’t that important to us,“You won’t care but I’ll say it anyway” which fits better with the depressed theme of the song.

My mother was of the sky
 My father was of the earth
 But I am of the universe

Julia, John’s mother, was a dreamer who struggled to deal with reality. She did not have much luck with jobs, and had to give up her first two children. She had her “head in the sky”.

Alfred, John’s father, unemotionally left John for a new life in New Zealand. Though he loved music, he was a practical man more than a loving one. He was “salt of the earth”.

John boldly claims to have got past those options. He isn’t just dreamy or practical, he’s both and more- he’s everything, like the universe.
“Feeling blue” is also used as a metaphor for depression. The “mist” makes it hard for John to feel anything different.

Black clouds are often used as a metaphor for depression.

They also signal the arrival of storms.
This refers to a character in Bob Dylan’s song titled, “Ballad of a Thin Man.”
